revision.text:
{{Taxobox | image = Angiostrongylus cantonensis.png | image_caption = Adult female worm of ''Angiostrongylus cantonensis'' with characteristic barber-pole appearance (anterior end of worm is to the top). Scale bar is 1 mm. | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[nematode|Nematoda]] | classis = [[Secernentea]] | ordo = [[Strongylida]] | familia = [[Metastrongylidae]] | genus = ''[[Angiostrongylus]]'' | species = '''''A. cantonensis''''' | binomial = ''Angiostrongylus cantonensis'' | binomial_authority = (Chen, 1935)<ref name="Chen 1935"/> }}
'''''Angiostrongylus cantonensis''''' is a [[parasite|parasitic]] [[nematode]] (roundworm) that causes [[angiostrongyliasis]], the most common cause of [[eosinophilic meningitis]] in [[Southeast Asia]] and the [[Pacific Basin]].<ref name=Baheti2008>{{cite journal | vauthors = Baheti NN, Sreedharan M, Krishnamoorthy T, Nair MD, Radhakrishnan K | title = Neurological picture. Eosinophilic meningitis and an ocular worm in a patient from Kerala, south India | journal = Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery, and Psychiatry | volume = 79 | issue = 3 | pages = 271 | date = March 2008 | pmid = 18281446 | pmc = 3106000| doi = 10.1136/jnnp.2007.122093 }}</ref> The nematode commonly resides in the pulmonary arteries of [[rat]]s, giving it the common name '''rat lungworm'''. [[Snail]]s are the primary intermediate [[Host (biology)|hosts]], where [[larva]]e develop until they are infectious.
Humans are incidental hosts of this roundworm, and may become infected through ingestion of [[larva]]e in raw or undercooked snails or other [[Vector (epidemiology)|vectors]], or from contaminated water and vegetables.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Hunter's tropical medicine and emerging infectious disease.|last=Magill |first=Alan J. |date=2012 |publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences |last2=Strickland |first2=G. Thomas |last3= Maguire |first3=James H. |last4=Ryan |first4=Edward T. |last5=Solomon |first5=Tom |isbn=9781455740437 |edition=9th |location=London |oclc=861539914}}</ref> The larvae are then transported via the blood to the [[central nervous system]], where they are the most common cause of [[eosinophilic meningitis]], a serious condition that can lead to death or permanent brain and nerve damage.<ref name=HuaLi2008>{{cite journal | vauthors = Li H, Xu F, Gu JB, Chen XG | title = A severe eosinophilic meningoencephalitis caused by infection of Angiostrongylus cantonensis | journal = The American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene | volume = 79 | issue = 4 | pages = 568–70 | date = October 2008 | pmid = 18840746 }}</ref> Angiostrongyliasis is an infection of increasing public health importance, as [[globalization]] contributes to the geographic spread of the disease.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Eamsobhana|first=P.|date=December 2014|title=Eosinophilic meningitis caused by Angiostrongylus cantonensis--a neglected disease with escalating importance|journal=Tropical Biomedicine|volume=31|issue=4|pages=569–578|issn=0127-5720|pmid=25776582}}</ref>
==History== First described by the renowned Chinese parasitologist [[Hsin-Tao Chen]] (1904–1977) in 1935, after examining Cantonese rat specimens,<ref name="Chen 1935">{{cite journal|last1=Chen|first1=H.-T.|title=Un nouveau nématode pulmonaire, ''Pulmonema cantonensis'', n. g., n. sp.|journal=Annales de Parasitologie Humaine et Comparée|volume=13|issue=4|year=1935|pages=312–317|url=https://www.parasite-journal.org/articles/parasite/abs/1935/04/parasite1935134p312/parasite1935134p312.html|doi=10.1051/parasite/1935134312}} {{open access}}</ref> the nematode ''Angiostrongylus cantonensis'' was identified in the [[cerebrospinal fluid]] of a patient with eosinophilic meningitis by Nomura and Lim in [[Taiwan]] in 1944. They noted that raw food eaten by the patient may have been contaminated by rats. In 1955, Mackerass and Sanders identified the lifecycle of the worm in rats, defining snails and slugs as the intermediate hosts and noting the path of transmission through the blood, brain, and lungs in rats.{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}}
==Infectious agent== [[File:Angiostrongylus cantonensis Male.jpg|left|thumb|186x186px|Male ''A. cantonensis'']] [[File:Angiostrongylus cantonensis 2.png|thumb|Tail of adult male of ''A. cantonensis'', showing copulatory bursa and long [[Spicule (nematode anatomy)|spicules]] (arrows), scale bar is 85 µm]] ''A. cantonensis'' is a [[parasitic worm|helminth]] of the [[phylum]] [[nematode|Nematoda]], [[order (biology)|order]] [[Strongylida]], and [[superfamily (zoology)|superfamily]] [[Metastrongyloidea]]. Nematodes are roundworms characterized by a tough outer [[Arthropod cuticle|cuticle]], unsegmented bodies, and a fully developed [[Human gastrointestinal tract|gastrointestinal tract]]. The order Strongylida includes [[Ancylostomatidae|hookworms]] and [[lungworm]]s. Metastrongyloidea are characterized as 2-cm-long,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/lab-bio/res/psds-ftss/acantonensis-eng.php|title=Pathogen Safety Data Sheet: Infectious Substances – Angiostrongylus cantonensis - Canada.ca|last=Canada|first=Public Health Agency of|date=|website=www.phac-aspc.gc.ca|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170714022751/http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/lab-bio/res/psds-ftss/acantonensis-eng.php|archive-date=2017-07-14|dead-url=no|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref> slender, threadlike worms that reside in the lungs of the definitive host.<ref name="Cambridge">{{cite web |title=Helminth Taxonomy - Phylum Nematoda |url=http://www.path.cam.ac.uk/~schisto/helminth_taxonomy/taxonomy_nematoda.html |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090413035903/http://www.path.cam.ac.uk/~schisto/helminth_taxonomy/taxonomy_nematoda.html |archive-date=April 13, 2009 |publisher=Schistosomiasis Research Group |access-date=26 February 2009}}</ref> ''[[Angiostrongylus costaricensis]]'' is a closely related worm that causes intestinal angiostrongyliasis in Central and South America.
==Epidemiology and pathogenesis== Following World War II, ''A. cantonensis'' spread throughout Southeast Asia and Western Pacific Islands, including [[Australia]], [[Melanesia]], [[Micronesia]], and [[Polynesia]]. Cases were soon reported in [[New Caledonia]], the [[Philippines]], [[Rarotonga]], [[Saipan]], [[Sumatra]], [[Taiwan]], and [[Tahiti]]. In the 1960s, even more cases were reported from the region from locations such as [[Cambodia]], [[Guam]], [[Hawaii]], [[Java]], [[Thailand]], [[Sarawak]], [[Vietnam]], and the New Hebrides ([[Vanuatu]]).<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.dhh.louisiana.gov/offices/miscdocs/docs-249/Manual/MeningitisEosinophilicManual.pdf|title=EOSINOPHILIC MENINGITIS|last=|first=|date=2018-03-09|website=louisiana.gov|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615214313/http://www.dhh.louisiana.gov/offices/miscdocs/docs-249/Manual/MeningitisEosinophilicManual.pdf|archive-date=2010-06-15|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
In 1961, an [[Epidemiology|epidemiological]] study of eosinophilic meningitis in humans was conducted by Rosen, Laigret, and Bories, who hypothesized that the parasite causing these infections was carried by fish. However, Alicata noted that raw fish was consumed by large numbers of people in Hawaii without apparent consequences, and patients presenting with meningitis symptoms had a history of eating raw snails or [[prawn]]s in the weeks before presenting with symptoms. This observation, along with epidemiology and [[autopsy]] of infected brains, confirmed ''A. cantonensis'' infection in humans as the cause of the majority of eosinophilic meningitis cases in Southeast Asia and the Pacific Islands.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Alicata|first=J.E.|title=The discovery of Angiostrongylus cantonensis as a cause of human eosinophilic meningitis|journal=Parasitology Today|volume=7|issue=6|pages=151–153|doi=10.1016/0169-4758(91)90285-v|year=1991}}</ref>
Since then, cases of ''A. cantonensis'' infestations have appeared in [[American Samoa]], Australia, [[Hong Kong]], [[Bombay]], [[Fiji]], Hawaii, [[Honshu]], [[India]], [[Kyushu]], [[New Britain]], [[Okinawa]], [[Ryukyu Islands]], [[Western Samoa]], and most recently mainland [[China]]. Other sporadic occurrences of the parasite in its rat hosts have been reported in [[Cuba]], [[Egypt]], [[Louisiana]], [[Madagascar]], [[Nigeria]], [[New Orleans]], and [[Puerto Rico]].<ref name=":4" />
In 2013, ''A. cantonensis'' was confirmed present in [[Florida]], USA, where its range and prevalence are expanding.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Iwanowicz DD, Sanders LR, Schill WB, Xayavong MV, da Silva AJ, Qvarnstrom Y, Smith T | title = Spread of the Rat Lungworm (Angiostrongylus cantonensis) in Giant African Land Snails (Lissachatina fulica) in Florida, USA | journal = Journal of Wildlife Diseases | volume = 51 | issue = 3 | pages = 749–53 | date = July 2015 | pmid = 25973628 | doi = 10.7589/2014-06-160 }}</ref> In 2018, a case was found in a [[New York City|New Yorker]], who had visited Hawaii.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/2-new-lungworm-cases-involves-n-y-teen-vacationed-hawaii-article-1.3931066|title=New York teen contracts rat lungworm during Hawaii vacation|last=|first=|date=|work=NY Daily News|access-date=2018-04-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180413052417/http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/2-new-lungworm-cases-involves-n-y-teen-vacationed-hawaii-article-1.3931066|archive-date=2018-04-13|dead-url=no|language=en}}</ref>
In recent years, the parasite has been shown to be proliferating at an alarming rate due to modern food-consumption trends and global transportation of food products. Scientists are calling for a more thorough study of the epidemiology of ''A. cantonensis'', stricter food-safety policies, and the increase of knowledge on how to properly consume products commonly infested by the parasite, such as snails and slugs that act as intermediate hosts or those that act as [[Host (biology)#Paratenic hosts|paratenic hosts]], such as fish, frogs, or [[Fresh water|freshwater]] prawns.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Lv S, Zhang Y, Steinmann P, Zhou XN | title = Emerging angiostrongyliasis in Mainland China | language = en-us | journal = Emerging Infectious Diseases | volume = 14 | issue = 1 | pages = 161–4 | date = January 2008 | pmid = 18258099 | pmc = 2600175 | doi = 10.3201/eid1401.061529 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Alicata|first=Joseph E.|date=1967|title=Effect of Freezing and Boiling on the Infectivity of Third-Stage Larvae of Angiostrongylus cantonensis Present in Land Snails and Freshwater Prawns|jstor=3276839|journal=The Journal of Parasitology|volume=53|issue=5|pages=1064–1066|doi=10.2307/3276839}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ash|first=Lawrence R.|date=1968|title=The Occurrence of Angiostrongylus cantonensis in Frogs of New Caledonia with Observations on Paratenic Hosts of Metastrongyles|jstor=3277060|journal=The Journal of Parasitology|volume=54|issue=3|pages=432–436|doi=10.2307/3277060}}</ref> Ingestion of food items that can be contaminated by the mucus excretions of intermediate or paratenic hosts, such as snails and slugs or by the feces of rats that act as definitive hosts, can lead to infection of ''A. cantonensis''.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Richards CS, Merritt JW | title = Studies on Angiostrongylus cantonensis in molluscan intermediate hosts | journal = The Journal of Parasitology | volume = 53 | issue = 2 | pages = 382–8 | date = April 1967 | pmid = 6022396 | doi = 10.2307/3276595 | jstor = 3276595 }}</ref> The most common route of infection of ''A. cantonesis'' in humans is by ingestion of either intermediate or paratenic hosts of the [[larva]]e.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Campbell BG, Little MD | title = The finding of Angiostrongylus cantonensis in rats in New Orleans | journal = The American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene | volume = 38 | issue = 3 | pages = 568–73 | date = May 1988 | pmid = 3275136 }}</ref> Unwashed fruits and vegetables, especially [[romaine lettuce]], can be contaminated with snail and slug mucus or can result in accidental ingestion of these intermediate and paratenic hosts. These items need to be properly washed and handled to prevent accidental ingestion of ''A. cantonensis'' larvae or the larvae-containing hosts.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Yeung NW, Hayes KA, Cowie RH | title = Effects of washing produce contaminated with the snail and slug hosts of Angiostrongylus cantonensis with three common household solutions | journal = Hawai'i Journal of Medicine & Public Health | volume = 72 | issue = 6 Suppl 2 | pages = 83–6 | date = June 2013 | pmid = 23901391 | pmc = 3689494 }}</ref> The best mechanism of prevention of ''A. cantonesis'' outbreak is to institute an aggressive control of snail and slug population, proper cooking of intermediate and paratenic hosts such as fish, freshwater prawn, frogs, [[Mollusca|mollusks]], and snails along with proper food-handling techniques.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Cowie RH | title = Pathways for transmission of angiostrongyliasis and the risk of disease associated with them | journal = Hawai'i Journal of Medicine & Public Health | volume = 72 | issue = 6 Suppl 2 | pages = 70–4 | date = June 2013 | pmid = 23901388 | pmc = 3689478 }}</ref> The common prevention techniques for diarrheal illness is very effective in preventing ''A. cantonensis'' infection.<ref name=":5">{{cite journal | vauthors = Slom TJ, Cortese MM, Gerber SI, Jones RC, Holtz TH, Lopez AS, Zambrano CH, Sufit RL, Sakolvaree Y, Chaicumpa W, Herwaldt BL, Johnson S | title = An outbreak of eosinophilic meningitis caused by Angiostrongylus cantonensis in travelers returning from the Caribbean | journal = The New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 346 | issue = 9 | pages = 668–75 | date = February 2002 | pmid = 11870244 | doi = 10.1056/NEJMoa012462 }}</ref> Not much is known about why it targets the brain in humans, but a chemically induced [[chemotaxis]] has been implicated recently. [[Acetylcholine]] has been previously reported to enhance motility of this worm via [[nicotinic acetylcholine receptor]]s.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Mentz MB, Graeff-Teixeira C | title = Drug trials for treatment of human angiostrongyliasis | journal = Revista do Instituto de Medicina Tropical de Sao Paulo | volume = 45 | issue = 4 | pages = 179–84 | date = July 2003 | pmid = 14502343 }}</ref> Experimental assays in animal models are needed to validate a [[Chemotaxis assay|chemically induced chemotaxis]] by use of [[anticholinergic]] drugs to prevent [[Cerebellum|cerebral]] infection following infections by ''A. cantonesis''.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Baig AM | title = Is There a Cholinergic Survival Incentive for Neurotropic Parasites in the Brain? | journal = ACS Chemical Neuroscience | volume = 8 | issue = 12 | pages = 2574–2577 | date = December 2017 | pmid = 28985043 | doi = 10.1021/acschemneuro.7b00370 }}</ref>
==Hosts== [[Host (biology)#Definitive and secondary hosts|Intermediate hosts]] of larvae of for ''A. cantonensis'' include: * Land snails: ''[[Thelidomus aspera]]'' from Jamaica,<ref name="Lindo">{{cite journal | vauthors = Lindo JF, Waugh C, Hall J, Cunningham-Myrie C, Ashley D, Eberhard ML, Sullivan JJ, Bishop HS, Robinson DG, Holtz T, Robinson RD | title = Enzootic Angiostrongylus cantonensis in rats and snails after an outbreak of human eosinophilic meningitis, JAMAica | journal = Emerging Infectious Diseases | volume = 8 | issue = 3 | pages = 324–6 | date = March 2002 | pmid = 11927033 | pmc = 2732477 | doi = 10.3201/eid0803.010316 | url = https://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol8no3/01-0316.htm }}</ref><ref name="Robinson 2013">{{cite journal | vauthors = Barth JD, Jansen H, Kromhout D, Reiber JH, Birkenhager JC, Arntzenius AC | title = Progression and regression of human coronary atherosclerosis. The role of lipoproteins, lipases and thyroid hormones in coronary lesion growth | journal = Atherosclerosis | volume = 68 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 51–8 | date = November 1987 | pmc = 3689483 | pmid = 3689483 }}</ref> ''[[Pleurodonte]]'' sp. from Jamaica, ''[[Sagda]]'' sp. from Jamaica, ''[[Poteria]]'' sp. from Jamaica,<ref name="Robinson 2013"/> ''[[Achatina fulica]]'',<ref name="Lv 2008">{{cite journal | vauthors = Lv S, Zhang Y, Steinmann P, Zhou XN | title = Emerging angiostrongyliasis in Mainland China | journal = Emerging Infectious Diseases | volume = 14 | issue = 1 | pages = 161–4 | date = January 2008 | pmid = 18258099 | pmc = 2600175 | doi = 10.3201/eid1401.061529 | url = http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/14/1/06-1529_article }}</ref><ref name="Lv2009"/><ref name="Asaro">{{cite journal |vauthors=Asato R, Taira K, Nakamura M, Kudaka J, Itokazu K, Kawanaka M |year=2004 |url=http://www.nih.go.jp/niid/JJID/57/184.pdf |title=Changing Epidemiology of Angiostrongyliasis Cantonensis in Okinawa Prefecture, Japan |journal=[[Japanese Journal of Infectious Diseases]] |volume=57 |pages=184–186}}</ref><ref name="airforcemedicine 2001"/> ''[[Satsuma mercatoria]]'', ''[[Acusta despecta]]'',<ref name="Asaro"/><ref name="airforcemedicine 2001"/> ''[[Bradybaena brevispira]]'',<ref name="Lv 2008"/> ''[[Bradybaena circulus]]''<ref name="Asaro"/> ''[[Bradybaena ravida]]'', ''[[Bradybaena similaris]]'', ''[[Plectotropis appanata]]''<ref name="Lv 2008"/> and ''[[Parmarion martensi]]'' from Okinawa<ref name="Asaro"/> and from Hawaii,<ref name="Hollingsworth">{{Cite journal | last1 = Hollingsworth | first1 = R. G. | last2 = Kaneta | first2 = R. | last3 = Sullivan | first3 = J. J. | last4 = Bishop | first4 = H. S. | last5 = Qvarnstrom | first5 = Y. | last6 = Da Silva | first6 = A. J. | last7 = Robinson | first7 = D. G. | name-list-format = vanc | title = Distribution of Parmarion cf. Martensi (Pulmonata: Helicarionidae), a New Semi-Slug Pest on Hawai'i Island, and Its Potential as a Vector for Human Angiostrongyliasis1 | journal = Pacific Science | volume = 61 | issue = 4 | pages = 457–467 | year = 2007 | doi = 10.2984/1534-6188(2007)61[457:DOPCMP]2.0.CO;2 | pmid = | pmc = | url = http://scholarspace.manoa.hawaii.edu/bitstream/10125/22629/1/vol61n4-457-467.pdf | type = Submitted manuscript | hdl = 10125/22629 }}.</ref> ''[[Camaena cicatricosa]]'', ''[[Trichochloritis rufopila]]'', ''[[Trichochloritis hungerfordianus]]'' and ''[[Cyclophorus (gastropod)|Cyclophorus]]'' spp.<ref name="airforcemedicine 2001">{{cite web |date=20 June 2001 |others="Land snail infection rates for the human parasitic nematode, ''Angiostrongylus cantonensis'' (rat lung worm) with notes on snail and parasite biology and distribution on Kadena AB, Okinawa Japan. Consultative Letter, IERA-DO-BR-CL-2001-0049." |title=MEMORANDUM FOR 18 MDG/SGPM |publisher=[[Department of the Air Force]] |url=http://airforcemedicine.afms.mil/idc/groups/public/documents/afms/ctb_020408.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811063829/http://airforcemedicine.afms.mil/idc/groups/public/documents/afms/ctb_020408.pdf |archive-date=2011-08-11 |dead-url=yes }}</ref> * Freshwater snails: ''[[Pila (gastropod)|Pila]]'' spp.,<ref name="Lv2009"/> ''[[Pomacea canaliculata]]'',<ref name="Lv 2008"/><ref name="Lv2009">{{cite journal | vauthors = Lv S, Zhang Y, Chen SR, Wang LB, Fang W, Chen F, Jiang JY, Li YL, Du ZW, Zhou XN | title = Human angiostrongyliasis outbreak in Dali, China | journal = PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases | volume = 3 | issue = 9 | pages = e520 | date = September 2009 | pmid = 19771154 | pmc = 2739427 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pntd.0000520 | editor1-last = Graeff-Teixeira | editor1-first = Carlos }}</ref> ''[[Cipangopaludina chinensis]]'', ''[[Bellamya aeruginosa]]'' and ''[[Bellamya quadrata]]''<ref name="Lv 2008"/> * [[Slug]]s: ''[[Limax maximus]]'',<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Senanayake SN, Pryor DS, Walker J, Konecny P | title = First report of human angiostrongyliasis acquired in Sydney | journal = The Medical Journal of Australia | volume = 179 | issue = 8 | pages = 430–1 | date = October 2003 | pmid = 14558868 }}</ref> ''[[Limax flavus]]''<ref name="Lv 2008"/> ''[[Deroceras laeve]]'',<ref name="Lv 2008"/><ref name="Högger 2003"/> ''[[Deroceras reticulatum]]'',<ref name="Högger 2003"/> ''[[Veronicella alte]]'',<ref name="Asaro"/> =? ''[[Laevicaulis alte]]'',<ref name="Lv 2008"/><ref name="Högger 2003"/> ''[[Sarasinula plebeia]]''<!-- listed as Vaginulus plebeius-->,<ref name="Högger 2003">Högger C. H. (update 25 March 2003). "Antagonists of Slugs and Snails. A Bibliography of Sources and a List of Citations grouped according to Taxon of the Antagonists". [https://web.archive.org/web/20071214020100/http://homepage.sunrise.ch/mysunrise/choegger/Slugs/Antagonists.html in web Archive].</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://homepage.sunrise.ch/mysunrise/choegger/Slugs/Antagonists.html|title=Christoph Högger - Antagonists of Slugs and Snails|last=|first=|date=2007-12-14|website=homepage.sunrise.ch/mysunrise/choegger|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080524010232/http://homepage.sunrise.ch/mysunrise/choegger/Slugs/Antagonists.html|archive-date=2008-05-24|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref> ''[[Vaginulus yuxjsjs]]'',<ref name="Lv 2008"/> ''[[Lehmannia valentiana]]'',<ref name="Asaro"/> ''[[Phiolomycus bilineatus]]'', ''[[Macrochlamys loana]]'', ''[[Meghimatium bilineatum]]''<ref name="Lv 2008"/> and probably other species of slugs.
[[Host (biology)#Definitive and secondary hosts|Definitive host]] of ''A. cantonensis'' include wild rodents, especially the brown rat (''[[Rattus norvegicus]]'') and the black rat (''[[Rattus rattus]]'').<ref name="Lindo"/>
[[Host (biology)#Paratenic hosts|Paratenic hosts]] of ''A. cantonensis'' include: predatory land flatworm ''[[Platydemus manokwari]]'' and amphibians ''[[Bufo asiaticus]]'', ''[[Rana catesbeiana]]'', ''[[Rhacophorus leucomystax]]'' and ''[[Rana limnocharis]]''.<ref name="Asaro"/>
In 2004, a captive [[yellow-tailed black cockatoo]] (''Calyptorhynchus funereus'') and two free-living [[tawny frogmouth]]s (''Podargus strigoides'') suffering neurological symptoms were shown to have the parasite. They were the first [[Bird|avian]] hosts discovered for the organism.<ref>{{Cite journal | vauthors = Monks DJ, Carlisle MS, Carrigan M, Rose K, Spratt D, Gallagher A, Prociv P | doi = 10.1647/2004-024.1 | title = Angiostrongylus cantonensis as a Cause of Cerebrospinal Disease in a Yellow-tailed Black Cockatoo (Calyptorhynchus funereus) and Two Tawny Frogmouths (Podargus strigoides) | journal = Journal of Avian Medicine and Surgery | volume = 19 | issue = 4 | pages = 289–293 | year = 2005 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref>
==Pathogenesis of human angiostrongylosis== The presence of parasitic worms burrowed in the neural tissue of the human [[central nervous system]] will cause obvious complications. All of the following will result in damage to the CNS:{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}}
# Direct mechanical damage to neural tissue from the worms' motion # Toxic byproducts such as nitrogenous waste # [[Antigen]]s released by dead and living parasites
==Eosinophilic meningitis== {{See also|Eosinophilic meningitis}} Although the clinical disease caused by ''Angiostrongylus'' invasion into the central nervous system is commonly referred to as "eosinophilic meningitis", the actual pathophysiology is of a meningoencephalitis with invasion not just of the [[meninges]], or superficial lining of the brain, but also deeper brain tissue. Initial invasion through the lining of the brain, the meninges, may cause a typical inflammation of the meninges and a classic meningitis picture of headache, stiff neck, and often fever. The parasites subsequently invade deeper into the brain tissue, causing specific localizing [[Neurological disorder|neurologic]] symptoms depending on where in the brain [[parenchyma]] they migrate. Neurologic findings and symptoms wax and wane as initial damage is done by the physical in-migration of the worms and secondary damage is done by the inflammatory response to the presence of dead and dying worms. This inflammation can lead in the short term to paralysis, bladder dysfunction, visual disturbance, and coma and in the long term to permanent nerve damage, mental retardation, nerve damage, permanent brain damage, or death.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal | vauthors = Wang QP, Lai DH, Zhu XQ, Chen XG, Lun ZR | title = Human angiostrongyliasis | journal = The Lancet. Infectious Diseases | volume = 8 | issue = 10 | pages = 621–30 | date = October 2008 | pmid = 18922484 | doi = 10.1016/S1473-3099(08)70229-9 }}</ref>
Eosinophilic meningitis is commonly defined by the increased number of [[eosinophil]]s in the [[cerebrospinal fluid]] (CSF). In most cases, eosinophil levels rise to 10 or more eosinophils per μl in the CSF, accounting for at least 10% of the total CSF [[White blood cell|leukocyte]] (white blood cell) count.<ref name="urlwww.dhh.louisiana.gov">[http://www.dhh.louisiana.gov/offices/miscdocs/docs-249/Manual/MeningitisEosinophilicManual.pdf "EOSINOPHILIC MENINGITIS"]. Revised 28 February 2006, accessed 1 June 2011.</ref> The chemical analysis of the CSF typically resembles the findings in "[[aseptic meningitis]]" with slightly elevated protein levels, normal glucose levels, and negative bacterial cultures. Presence of a significantly decreased glucose on CSF analysis is an indicator of severe [[meningoencephalitis]] and may indicate a poor [[Prognosis|medical outcome]]. Initial CSF analysis early in the disease process may occasionally show no increase of eosinophils, only to have classical increases in eosinophils in subsequent CSF analysis. Caution should be advised in using eosinophilic meningitis as the only criterion for diagnosing angiostrongylus infestation in someone with classic symptoms, as the disease evolves with the migration of the worms into the CNS.{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}}
Eosinophils are specialized white blood cells of the [[Granulocyte|granulocytic]] cell line which contain granules in their [[cytoplasm]]. These granules contain proteins that are toxic to parasites. When these granules degranulate, or break down, chemicals are released that combat parasites such as ''A. cantonensis''. Eosinophils, which are located throughout the body, are guided to sites of inflammation by [[chemokine]]s when the body is infested with parasites such as ''A. cantonensis''. Once at the site of inflammation, type 2 cytokines are released from [[T helper cell|helper T cells]], which communicate with the eosinophils, signaling them to activate. Once activated, eosinophils can begin the process of [[degranulation]], releasing their toxic [[protein]]s in the fight against the foreign parasite.{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}}
===Clinical signs and symptoms=== According to a group [[case study]], the most common symptoms in mild eosinophilic meningitis tend to be headache (with 100% of people in the study suffering from this symptom), [[photophobia]] or visual disturbance (92%), neck stiffness (83%), fatigue (83%), [[hyperesthesia]]s (75%), vomiting (67%), and [[paresthesia]]s (50%).<ref name="Murphy 35–40" /><ref name=":5" /> [[Incubation period]] is often 3 weeks, but can be 3–36 days<ref name=":4" /> and even 80 days.<ref name=":6">{{cite journal | vauthors = Tseng YT, Tsai HC, Sy CL, Lee SS, Wann SR, Wang YH, Chen JK, Wu KS, Chen YS | title = Clinical manifestations of eosinophilic meningitis caused by Angiostrongylus cantonensis: 18 years' experience in a medical center in southern Taiwan | journal = Journal of Microbiology, Immunology, and Infection = Wei Mian Yu Gan Ran Za Zhi | volume = 44 | issue = 5 | pages = 382–9 | date = October 2011 | pmid = 21524976 | doi = 10.1016/j.jmii.2011.01.034 }}</ref>
Possible clinical [[Medical sign|signs]] and [[symptom]]s of mild and severe eosinophilic meningitis are: * Fever is often minor or absent, but the presence of high fever suggests severe disease.<ref name="Murphy 35–40" /> * Headaches are progressive and severe,<ref name="Murphy 35–40" /> a bitemporal character in the frontal or [[Occipital lobe|occipital]] lobe.<ref name=":4" /> * [[Meningism]]us - neck stiffness<ref name="Murphy 35–40" /> * [[Photophobia]] - sensitivity to light<ref name="Murphy 35–40" /> * Muscle weakness and fatigue<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":6" /> * Nausea with or without vomiting<ref name=":4" /><ref name="Murphy 35–40" /> * Paresthesias - tingling, prickling, or numbing of skin, may last for several weeks or months<ref name=":4" /> * Hyperesthesia - severe sensitivity to touch; may last for several weeks or months<ref name="Murphy 35–40" /> * [[Radicular pain|Radiculitis]] - pain irradiated along certain areas of skin<ref name="Murphy 35–40" /> * Bladder dysfunction with [[urinary retention]]<ref name=":7" /> * Constipation<ref name=":7">{{cite journal | vauthors = Maretić T, Perović M, Vince A, Lukas D, Dekumyoy P, Begovac J | title = Meningitis and radiculomyelitis caused by Angiostrongylus cantonensis | journal = Emerging Infectious Diseases | volume = 15 | issue = 6 | pages = 996–8 | date = June 2009 | pmid = 19523323 | pmc = 2727321 | doi = 10.3201/eid1506.081263 }}</ref> * [[Brudziński's sign|Brudziński’s sign]]<ref name=":6" /> * [[Vertigo]] * [[Visual impairment|Blindness]] * [[Paralysis]] localized to one area; e.g. paralysis of [[extraocular muscles]] and [[Facial nerve paralysis|facial palsy]]<ref name=":6" /> * General paralysis ([[Flaccid paralysis|flaccid]])<ref name=":4" /> often ascending in nature starting with the feet and progressing upwards to involve the entire body * [[Coma]]<ref name="Murphy 35–40" /> * Death<ref name="Murphy 35–40" />
===Treatment=== The severity and clinical course of ''Angiostrongylus'' disease depends significantly on the ingested load of third-stage [[larva]]e,<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Tsai HC, Liu YC, Kunin CM, Lee SS, Chen YS, Lin HH, Tsai TH, Lin WR, Huang CK, Yen MY, Yen CM | title = Eosinophilic meningitis caused by Angiostrongylus cantonensis: report of 17 cases | journal = The American Journal of Medicine | volume = 111 | issue = 2 | pages = 109–14 | date = August 2001 | pmid = 11498063 | doi = 10.1016/S0002-9343(01)00766-5 }}</ref> creating great variability from case to case, making clinical trials difficult to design, and effectiveness of treatments difficult to discern. Typical conservative medical management including [[analgesic]]s and [[sedative]]s provide minimal relief for the headaches and hyperesthesias. Removing cerebrospinal fluid at regular 3- to 7-day intervals is the only proven method of significantly reducing [[intracranial pressure]] and can be used for symptomatic treatment of headaches.<ref name="Slom 668–675">{{cite journal | vauthors = Slom TJ, Cortese MM, Gerber SI, Jones RC, Holtz TH, Lopez AS, Zambrano CH, Sufit RL, Sakolvaree Y, Chaicumpa W, Herwaldt BL, Johnson S | title = An outbreak of eosinophilic meningitis caused by Angiostrongylus cantonensis in travelers returning from the Caribbean | journal = The New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 346 | issue = 9 | pages = 668–75 | date = February 2002 | pmid = 11870244 | doi = 10.1056/nejmoa012462 }}</ref> This process may be repeated until improvement is shown.<ref name="urlwww.dhh.louisiana.gov"/> There is growing evidence of moderate quality that suggests [[corticosteroid]] therapy using [[prednisolone]]<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Chotmongkol|first=V|date=2006|title=Treatment of eosinophilic meningitis with a combination of prednisolone and mebendazole.|url=|journal=Am J Trop Med Hyg|volume=74|pages=1122–1124}}</ref> or [[dexamethasone]]<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Tsai|first=TH|date=2001|title=An outbreak of meningitis caused by Angiostrongylus cantonensis in Kaohsiung.|url=|journal=J Microbiol Immunol Infect|volume=34|pages=50–56}}</ref> has beneficial effect in treating the [[Central nervous system|CNS]] symptoms related to ''A. cantonensis'' infections.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Chotmongkol V, Sawanyawisuth K, Thavornpitak Y | title = Corticosteroid treatment of eosinophilic meningitis | journal = Clinical Infectious Diseases | volume = 31 | issue = 3 | pages = 660–2 | date = September 2000 | pmid = 11017811 | doi = 10.1086/314036 | url = https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/31/3/660/296029/Corticosteroid-Treatment-of-Eosinophilic }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Thanaviratananich S, Thanaviratananich S, Ngamjarus C | title = Corticosteroids for parasitic eosinophilic meningitis | journal = The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews | issue = 2 | pages = CD009088 | date = February 2015 | pmid = 25687750 | doi = 10.1002/14651858.CD009088.pub3 | url = https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMH0049384/ }}</ref> Although early research did not show treatment with [[Anthelmintic|antihelminthic]] agents (parasite-killing drugs) such as [[Tiabendazole|thiobendazole]] or [[albendazole]] effective in improving the clinical course of the illness,<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kliks MM, Kroenke K, Hardman JM | title = Eosinophilic radiculomyeloencephalitis: an angiostrongyliasis outbreak in American Samoa related to ingestion of Achatina fulica snails | journal = The American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene | volume = 31 | issue = 6 | pages = 1114–22 | date = November 1982 | pmid = 7149098 | doi = 10.4269/ajtmh.1982.31.1114 }}</ref><ref name="Murphy 35–40">{{cite journal | vauthors = Murphy GS, Johnson S | title = Clinical aspects of eosinophilic meningitis and meningoencephalitis caused by Angiostrongylus cantonensis, the rat lungworm | journal = Hawai'i Journal of Medicine & Public Health | volume = 72 | issue = 6 Suppl 2 | pages = 35–40 | date = June 2013 | pmid = 23901382 | pmc = 3689484 }}</ref> a number of recent studies from Thailand and China show that the combination of [[glucocorticoid]]s and antihelminthics is safe and decreases the duration of headaches and the number of patients who had significant headache.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":1" /><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Jitpimolmard S, Sawanyawisuth K, Morakote N, Vejjajiva A, Puntumetakul M, Sanchaisuriya K, Tassaneeyakul W, Tassaneeyakul W, Korwanich N | title = Albendazole therapy for eosinophilic meningitis caused by Angiostrongylus cantonensis | journal = Parasitology Research | volume = 100 | issue = 6 | pages = 1293–6 | date = May 2007 | pmid = 17177056 | doi = 10.1007/s00436-006-0405-7 }}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Chotmongkol|first=V|date=2004|title=Treatment of eosinophilic meningitis with a combination of albendazole and corticosteroid.|url=|journal=Southeast Asian J Trop Med Public Health|volume=35|pages=172–74}}</ref> Although the addition of antihelminthic agents for management of ''A. cantonensis'' infection has a theoretic risk of precipitating a neurologic crisis by releasing an overwhelming load of [[antigen]]s through simultaneous death of the larvae,<ref name="Slom 668–675"/> no study has shown this to exist in the clinical setting.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Chotmongkol V, Sawanyawisuth K, Thavornpitak Y | title = Corticosteroid treatment of eosinophilic meningitis | journal = Clinical Infectious Diseases | volume = 31 | issue = 3 | pages = 660–2 | date = September 2000 | pmid = 11017811 | doi = 10.1086/314036 }}</ref><ref name=":3" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":1" /> Additionally, the failure to kill parasites before they attempt to migrate out of the CNS increases the risk of mechanical damage by migrating larvae. Although combination therapy using albendazole and prednisolone has no significant advantage compared to treatment using prednisolone alone in mild cases,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chotmongkol|first=Verajit|last2=Kittimongkolma|first2=Suvicha|last3=Niwattayakul|first3=Kanigar|last4=Intapan|first4=Pewpan M.|last5=Thavornpitak|first5=Yupa|date=2009-09-01|title=Comparison of Prednisolone Plus Albendazole with Prednisolone Alone for Treatment of Patients with Eosinophilic Meningitis|journal=The American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene|language=en|volume=81|issue=3|pages=443–445|doi=10.4269/ajtmh.2009.81.443|issn=0002-9637}}</ref> the treatment with antihelminthics is demonstrably safe and may have significant benefit for patients with high parasite loads at risk for permanent disability or death.<ref name=":0" /> <!-- Further studies to better define treatment regimens for mild, moderate, and severe disease would be extremely useful, but have not yet been performed due to the technical difficulties mentioned above. --> === Diagnosis === The diagnosis of disease caused by ''A. cantonensis'' infestation is often difficult and relies heavily on the history of a likely ingestion of a commonly infested host and the presence of typical features of the disease. The presumptive diagnosis is particularly strong when eosinophilic meningoencephalitis can be confirmed. The diagnosis of eosinophilic meningitis can be arrived at through detection of elevated cranial pressure and increased numbers of eosinophils. The diagnosis of the cause of eosinophilic meningitis and the presence of ''A. cantonensis'' is remarkably more difficult. A [[Lumbar puncture|spinal tap]], or a sample of CSF, must be taken to search for ''A. cantonensis'' worms or larvae. ''A. cantonensis'' is undetectable in the CSF of more than half of the infected individuals. Current methods of detecting specific antigens associated with ''A. cantonensis'' are also unreliable. Consequently, alternative approaches to detect antigen-[[antibody]] reactions are being explored, such as [[Agglutination-PCR|immuno-PCR]].<ref name="urlImmuno-PCR for Detection of Antigen to Angiostrongylus cantonensis Circulating Fifth-Stage Worms -- Chye et al. 50 (1): 51 -- Clinical Chemistry">{{cite journal | vauthors = Chye SM, Lin SR, Chen YL, Chung LY, Yen CM | title = Immuno-PCR for detection of antigen to Angiostrongylus cantonensis circulating fifth-stage worms | journal = Clinical Chemistry | volume = 50 | issue = 1 | pages = 51–7 | date = January 2004 | pmid = 14709636 | pmc = | doi = 10.1373/clinchem.2003.020867 }}</ref> A rapid dot-blot [[ELISA|ELISA test]] is also available for quick, effective, and economical on-site diagnosis of ''A. cantonensis''.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Eamsobhana P, Yong HS | title = Immunological diagnosis of human angiostrongyliasis due to Angiostrongylus cantonensis (Nematoda: Angiostrongylidae) | journal = International Journal of Infectious Diseases | volume = 13 | issue = 4 | pages = 425–31 | date = July 2009 | pmid = 19117782 | doi = 10.1016/j.ijid.2008.09.021 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1201971208016834 }}</ref>

[[File:Subduction-en.svg|thumb|450px|A back-arc above a subduction zone]] The '''back-arc region''' is the area behind a [[volcanic arc]].<ref name=moores>{{cite book|title=Tectonics|first=Eldridge M.|last=Moores|first2=Robert J.|last2=Twiss|year=1995|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QERcN2XEYwQC&pg=PA173|publisher=[[W. H. Freeman and Company]]|page=157|isbn=978-0-7167-2437-7}}</ref> In [[island arc|island volcanic arc]]s it consists of [[back-arc basin]]s of [[oceanic crust]] with [[abyssal depth]]s, which may be separated by '''remnant arcs''', similar to island arcs.<ref name=moores/> In [[continental arc]]s the back-arc region is part of [[continental platform]], either dry land ([[subaerial]]) or forming shallow marine basins.<ref name=moores/>
==Formation== Back-arc deformation is a product of [[subduction]] at [[convergent boundary|convergent plate tectonic]] boundaries. It initiates and evolves behind the [[volcanic arc]] on the overriding plate of a subduction zone.<ref name=heuret05>{{Citation | last = Heuret, A. | first = Lallemand, S. | title = Plate motions, slab dynamics and back-arc deformation | journal = Physics of the Earth and Planetary Interiors | volume = 149 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 31–51 | date = March 2005 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0031920104003462 | doi = 10.1016/j.pepi.2004.08.022 | bibcode = 2005PEPI..149...31H }}</ref> The stresses responsible for the deformation in this region of a subduction zone result from a combination of processes. The absolute motion of the upper plate as it moves towards or away from the [[oceanic trench|trench]] strongly contributes to deformation in the back-arc region.<ref name=heuret05/> Since the downgoing slab is partly anchored in the viscous layers of the mantle, and therefore its lateral movement is significantly slower than the surface plate, then any motion of the overriding plate will cause extensional or compressional stress in the back-arc region depending on the direction of motion.<ref name=heuret05/> In addition, mantle convection in the upper mantle wedge caused by the downward movement of the subducted slab causes stress in the upper plate and the high heat flow that characterizes back-arcs.<ref>{{Citation | last = Uyeda | first = S. | title = Subduction zones: An introduction to comparative subductology | journal = Tectonophysics | volume = 81 | issue = 3–4 | pages = 133–159 | date = January 1982 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0040195182901263 | doi = 10.1016/0040-1951(82)90126-3 | bibcode = 1982Tectp..81..133U }}</ref> The pulling effect of the slab as it goes down into the mantle causes a rollback motion of the trench, which also applies stress on the back-arc region of the upper plate.<ref name=heuret05/> However, this last process has less of an impact on deformation compared to upper plate motion.<ref name=heuret05/>
Back-arcs can form on either oceanic crust or continental crust. In the case of oceanic crust, most back-arc regions are subjected to tensional stresses and thus develop a spreading center where new oceanic crust is formed.<ref name=tay03>{{Citation | last = Taylor, B. | first = Martinez, F. | title = Back-arc basin basalt systematics | journal = Earth and Planetary Science Letters | volume = 210 | issue = 3–4 | pages = 481–497 | date = May 2003 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0012821X03001675 | doi = 10.1016/S0012-821X(03)00167-5 | bibcode = 2003E&PSL.210..481T }}</ref> The composition of this new crust is similar to MORB, although it contains higher amounts of water.<ref name=tay03/>
==Back-arc extension vs. compression== The back-arc deformation may be either extensional or compressional. The overriding plate will shorten when its motion is directed towards the trench, resulting in a compression of the back-arc region.<ref name=heuret07>{{Citation | last = Heuret | first = A. | last2 = Funiciello | first2 = F. | last3 = Faccenna | first3 = C. | last4 = Lallemand | first4 = S. | title = Plate kinematics, slab shape and back-arc stress: A comparison between laboratory models and current subduction zones | journal = Earth and Planetary Science Letters | volume = 256 | issue = 3–4 | pages = 473–483 | date = April 2007 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0012821X07000696 | doi = 10.1016/j.epsl.2007.02.004 | bibcode = 2007E&PSL.256..473H }}</ref> This type of deformation is associated with a shallow dipping subducted slab.<ref name=heuret07/> Inversely, an overriding plate moving away from the trench will result in extension, and a back-arc basin will form.<ref name=heuret07/> This extensional deformation is associated with a steeply dipping slab.<ref name=heuret07/>
The extreme cases of these two types of back-arc deformation can be found in Chile and at the [[Izu-Bonin-Mariana Arc|Marianas arc]]. The shallow dipping slab subducting beneath Chile at an angle of about 10–15° causes a compressional stress on the back-arc region behind the Andes.<ref name=u79>{{Citation | last = Uyeda, |first= S. | last2= Kanamori | first2 = H. | authorlink2 = Hiroo Kanamori | title = Back-arc opening and the mode of subduction | journal = Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth | volume = 84 | issue = B3 | pages = 1049–1061 | date = March 1979 | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/JB084iB03p01049/abstract | doi = 10.1029/JB084iB03p01049 |bibcode= 1979JGR....84.1049U }}</ref> On the other extreme, the slab going down into the mantle at the Marianas subduction zone is so steep it is nearly vertical.<ref name=u79/> This is the perfect example of an oceanic back-arc basin experiencing extensional forces. The Oriente in Ecuador (the eastern part of the country covered by rainforest) is also a good example of an extensional back-arc basin, this time in a continental setting. The continental crust in this area east of the Andes has been stretched out and covered by layers of sediments.
==See also== *[[Forearc]] *[[Foreland basin]]

{{Other uses}} {{star nav}} In [[astronomy]], a '''blue giant''' is a hot [[star]] with a [[luminosity]] class of III ([[giant star|giant]]) or II ([[bright giant]]). In the standard [[Hertzsprung–Russell diagram]], these stars lie above and to the right of the [[main sequence]].
The term applies to a variety of stars in different phases of development, all evolved stars that have moved from the main sequence but have little else in common, so blue giant simply refers to stars in a particular region of the HR diagram rather than a specific type of star. They are much rarer than [[red giant]]s, because they only develop from more massive and less common stars, and because they have short lives in the blue giant stage.
The name blue giant is sometimes misapplied to other high-mass luminous stars, such as main-sequence stars, simply because they are large and hot.<ref name=wrong>{{cite web|url=https://www.quora.com/What-is-the-life-cycle-of-a-blue-giant-star|title=What is the life cycle of a blue giant star?|accessdate=2017-12-11}}</ref>
==Properties== [[Image:1e9m comparison Gamma Orionis, Algol B, the Sun, and smaller - antialiased no transparency.png|thumb|250px|left|Blue giant [[Bellatrix]] compared to [[Algol|Algol B]], the [[Sun]], a red dwarf, and some planets.]] Blue giant is not a strictly defined term and it is applied to a wide variety of different types of stars. What they have in common is: a moderate increase in size and luminosity compared to main-sequence stars of the same mass or temperature, and are hot enough to be called blue, meaning spectral class O, B, and sometimes early A. They have temperatures from around 10,000 K upwards, [[zero age main sequence]] (ZAMS) masses greater than about twice the Sun ({{Solar mass|link=y}}), and absolute magnitudes around 0 or brighter. These stars are only 5–10 times the radius of the Sun ({{Solar radius|link=y}}), compared to red giants which are up to {{Solar radius|100|link=y}}.
The coolest and least luminous stars referred to as blue giants are on the [[horizontal branch]], intermediate-mass stars that have passed through a red giant phase and are now burning [[helium]] in their cores. Depending on mass and chemical composition these stars gradually move bluewards until they exhaust the helium in their cores and then they return redwards to the [[asymptotic giant branch]] (AGB). The [[RR Lyrae variable]] stars, usually with spectral types of A, lie across the middle of the horizontal branch. Horizontal-branch stars hotter than the RR Lyrae gap are generally considered to be blue giants, and sometimes the RR Lyrae stars themselves are called blue giants despite some of them being F class.<ref name=rrlyr>{{Cite journal | last1 = Lee | first1 = Y. -W. | doi = 10.1086/169326 | title = On the Sandage period shift effect among field RR Lyrae stars | journal = The Astrophysical Journal | volume = 363 | pages = 159 | year = 1990 | pmid = | pmc = |bibcode = 1990ApJ...363..159L }}</ref> The hottest stars, blue horizontal branch (BHB) stars, are called extreme horizontal branch (EHB) stars and can be hotter than main-sequence stars of the same luminosity. In these cases they are called blue subdwarf (sdB) stars rather than blue giants, named for their position to the left of the main sequence on the HR diagram rather than for their increased luminosity and temperature compared to when they were themselves main-sequence stars.<ref name=sdb>{{Cite journal | last1 = Geier | first1 = S. | last2 = Heber | first2 = U. | last3 = Heuser | first3 = C. | last4 = Classen | first4 = L. | last5 = o’Toole | first5 = S. J. | last6 = Edelmann | first6 = H. | doi = 10.1051/0004-6361/201220964 | title = The subdwarf B star SB 290 – A fast rotator on the extreme horizontal branch | journal = Astronomy & Astrophysics | volume = 551 | pages = L4 | year = 2013 | pmid = | pmc = |arxiv = 1301.4129 |bibcode = 2013A&A...551L...4G }}</ref>
There are no strict upper limits for giant stars, but early O types become increasingly difficult to classify separately from main sequence and supergiant stars, have almost identical sizes and temperatures to the main-sequence stars from which they develop, and very short lifetimes. A good example is [[Plaskett's star]], a close binary consisting of two O type giants both over {{Solar mass|50}}, temperatures over 30,000 K, and more than 100,000 times the luminosity of the Sun ({{Solar luminosity}}). Astronomers still differ over whether to classify at least one of the stars as a supergiant, based on subtle differences in the spectral lines.<ref name=plasketts>{{Cite journal | last1 = Linder | first1 = N. | last2 = Rauw | first2 = G. | last3 = Martins | first3 = F. | last4 = Sana | first4 = H. | last5 = De Becker | first5 = M. | last6 = Gosset | first6 = E. | doi = 10.1051/0004-6361:200810003 | title = High-resolution optical spectroscopy of Plaskett's star | journal = Astronomy and Astrophysics | volume = 489 | issue = 2 | pages = 713 | year = 2008 | pmid = | pmc = |arxiv = 0807.4823 |bibcode = 2008A&A...489..713L }}</ref>
==Evolution== [[Image:Alcyon (star).jpg|thumb|250px|right|[[Alcyone (star)|Alcyone]], a typical blue giant]] Stars found in the blue giant region of the HR diagram can be in very different stages of their lives, but all are evolved stars that have largely exhausted their core hydrogen supplies.
In the simplest case, a hot luminous star begins to expand as its core hydrogen is exhausted, and first becomes a blue subgiant then a blue giant, becoming both cooler and more luminous. Intermediate-mass stars will continue to expand and cool until they become red giants. Massive stars also continue to expand as hydrogen shell burning progresses, but they do so at approximately constant luminosity and move horizontally across the HR diagram. In this way they can quickly pass through blue giant, bright blue giant, blue supergiant, and yellow supergiant classes, until they become red supergiants. The luminosity class for such stars is determined from spectral lines that are sensitive to the surface gravity of the star, with more expanded and luminous stars being given '''I''' (supergiant) classifications while somewhat less expanded and more luminous stars are given luminosity '''II''' or '''III'''.<ref name=evolution>{{Cite journal | last1 = Iben | first1 = I. | last2 = Renzini | first2 = A. | doi = 10.1016/0370-1573(84)90142-X | title = Single star evolution I. Massive stars and early evolution of low and intermediate mass stars | journal = Physics Reports | volume = 105 | issue = 6 | pages = 329 | year = 1984 | pmid = | pmc = |bibcode = 1984PhR...105..329I }}</ref> Because they are massive stars with short lives, many blue giants are found in [[OB association|O-B associations]], that are large collections of loosely bound young stars.
BHB stars are more evolved and have helium burning cores, although they still have an extensive hydrogen envelope. They also have moderate masses around {{Solar mass|0.5–1.0}} so they are often much older than more massive blue giants.<ref name=bhb>{{Cite journal | last1 = Da Costa | first1 = G. S. | last2 = Rejkuba | first2 = M. | last3 = Jerjen | first3 = H. | last4 = Grebel | first4 = E. K. | title = Ancient Stars Beyond the Local Group: RR Lyrae Variables and Blue Horizontal Branch Stars in Sculptor Group Dwarf Galaxies | doi = 10.1088/2041-8205/708/2/L121 | journal = The Astrophysical Journal | volume = 708 | issue = 2 | pages = L121 | year = 2010 | pmid = | pmc = |arxiv = 0912.1069 |bibcode = 2010ApJ...708L.121D }}</ref> The BHB takes its name from the prominent horizontal grouping of stars seen on colour-magnitude diagrams for older clusters, where core helium burning stars of the same age are found at a variety of temperatures with roughly the same luminosity. These stars also evolve through the core helium burning stage at constant luminosity, first increasing in temperature then decreasing again as they move toward the AGB. However, at the blue end of the horizontal branch, it forms a "blue tail" of stars with lower luminosity, and occasionally a "blue hook" of even hotter stars.<ref name=bluetail>{{Cite journal | last1 = Cassisi | first1 = S. | last2 = Salaris | first2 = M. | last3 = Anderson | first3 = J. | last4 = Piotto | first4 = G. | last5 = Pietrinferni | first5 = A. | last6 = Milone | first6 = A. | last7 = Bellini | first7 = A. | last8 = Bedin | first8 = L. R. | doi = 10.1088/0004-637X/702/2/1530 | title = Hot Horizontal Branch Stars in ω Centauri: Clues about their Origin from the Cluster Color Magnitude Diagram| journal = The Astrophysical Journal | volume = 702 | issue = 2 | pages = 1530 | year = 2009 | pmid = | pmc = |arxiv = 0907.3550 |bibcode = 2009ApJ...702.1530C }}</ref>
There are other highly evolved hot stars not generally referred to as blue giants: [[Wolf–Rayet star]]s, highly luminous and distinguished by their extreme temperatures and prominent helium and nitrogen emission lines; post-AGB stars forming [[planetary nebulae]], similar to Wolf–Rayet stars but smaller and less massive; [[blue straggler]]s, uncommon luminous blue stars observed apparently on the main sequence in clusters where main-sequence stars of their luminosity should have evolved into giants or supergiants; and the true [[blue supergiant]]s, the most massive stars evolved beyond blue giants and identified by the effects of greater expansion on their spectra.
A purely theoretical group of stars could be formed when [[red dwarf]]s finally exhaust their core hydrogen trillions of years into the future. These stars are convective through their depth and are expected to very slowly increase both their temperature and luminosity as they accumulate more and more helium until eventually they cannot sustain fusion and they quickly collapse to white dwarfs. Although these stars can become hotter than the [[Sun]] they will never become more luminous, so are hardly blue giants as we see them today. The name [[blue dwarf (red dwarf stage)|blue dwarf]] has been coined although that name could easily be confusing.<ref name=lowmass>{{Cite journal | last1 = Adams | first1 = F. C. | last2 = Bodenheimer | first2 = P. | last3 = Laughlin | first3 = G. | doi = 10.1002/asna.200510440 | title = M dwarfs: Planet formation and long term evolution | journal = Astronomische Nachrichten | volume = 326 | issue = 10 | pages = 913 | year = 2005 | pmid = | pmc = |bibcode = 2005AN....326..913A }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{wiktionary}}
{{Star}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Blue Giant}} [[Category:Star types]] [[Category:Stellar phenomena]] [[Category:O-type giants| ]] [[Category:B-type giants| ]] [[Category:Giant stars]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox mineral | name = claudetite | category = [[Oxide minerals]] | boxwidth = | boxbgcolor = | image = Claudetite-I-layer-3D-balls.png | caption = | formula = As2 O3 | molweight = | strunz = 4.CB.45 | system = [[Monoclinic]] | class = Prismatic (2/m)
(same [[H-M symbol]]) | symmetry = ''P2''1/n | unit cell = a = 5.33 Å, b = 12.98 Å,
c = 4.54 Å; β = 94.27°; Z = 4 | color = Colorless to white | habit = Thin tabular crystals, fibrous crusts | twinning = Contact or penetration on {100} | cleavage = Perfect on {010} micaceous | fracture = Splintery | tenacity = Flexible | mohs = 2.15 | luster = Vitreous, pearly on cleavage surfaces | refractive = nα = 1.870 nβ = 1.920 nγ = 2.010 | opticalprop = Biaxial (-) | birefringence = δ = 0.140 | 2V = 58° (measured) | pleochroism = | streak = | gravity = 4.14 - 4.15 | melt = | fusibility = | diagnostic = | solubility = | diaphaneity = Transparent | other = | references = [http://rruff.geo.arizona.edu/doclib/hom/claudetite.pdf Handbook of Mineralogy][http://webmineral.com/data/Claudetite.shtml Claudetite data on Webmineral][http://www.mindat.org/min-1060.html Claudetite on Mindat] }} '''Claudetite''' is an arsenic [[oxide mineral]] with chemical formula [[arsenic trioxide|As2O3]]. Claudetite is formed as an [[Redox|oxidation]] product of arsenic [[Sulfide mineral|sulfides]] and is colorless or white. It can be associated with [[arsenolite]] (the cubic form of As2O3) as well as [[realgar]] (As4S4), [[orpiment]] (As2S3) and [[native sulfur]]. It was first described in 1868 for an occurrence in the San Domingo mines, [[Algarve]], [[Portugal]]. It was first described by and named for the French chemist [[Frederick Claudet]]. == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Arsenic minerals]] [[Category:Oxide minerals]] [[Category:Monoclinic minerals]] {{oxide-mineral-stub}}

revision.text:
[[Image:cruelty1.JPG|thumb|right|250px|William Hogarth's ''First Stage of Cruelty'' shows schoolboys cock throwing, though it was dangerous practice to hold the rooster while others threw at it.]]
'''Cock throwing''', also known as '''cock-shying''' or '''throwing at cocks''', was a [[blood sport]] widely practised in England until the late 18th century. A [[rooster]] was tied to a post, and people took turns throwing coksteles (special weighted sticks) at the bird until it died. Cock throwing was traditionally associated with [[Shrove Tuesday]]; a contributor to ''[[The Gentleman's Magazine]]'' in 1737, during an anti-Gallican phase of British culture, was of the opinion that cock throwing arose from traditional enmity towards the French, for which the cock played an emblematic role.<ref name="GM">{{cite web|url=http://animalrightshistory.org/animal-rights-timeline/animal-rights-g/gentlemans-magazine/1737-01-enquiry.htm|title=Gentleman's Magazine:An Enquiry into the Original Meaning of Cock-Throwing on Shrove-Tuesday|date=1737|accessdate=19 January 2007}}</ref>
Cock throwing was a popular pastime with people of all classes, especially with children, and although widespread, was less common than [[cockfighting]].<ref name="TBRS">{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Traditional British Rural Sports|author=Wray Vamplew|publisher=Routledge|date=2005|pages=301|isbn=0-415-35224-X}}</ref> Sir [[Thomas More]] referred to his skill in casting a cokstele as a boy. If the bird had its legs broken or was lamed during the event, it was sometimes supported with sticks in order to prolong the game. The cock was also sometimes placed inside an earthenware jar to prevent it from moving.<ref name="Pastimes">{{cite web|url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/neu/eng/spe/index.htm|title=Sports and Pastimes of the People of England: Chapter VII|author=Joseph Strutt|date=1903|accessdate=19 January 2007}}</ref> Variations on the theme included goose quailing (or squailing), when a goose was substituted, and cock thrashing or cock whipping, which involved a cock being placed in a pit where the blindfolded participants would attempt to hit it with their sticks. A Sussex variation was similar to [[bull-baiting]] with the rooster tied to a {{convert|4|or|5|ft|m|adj=mid|-long}} cord.<ref name="TBRS" />
[[Image:Cockthrowing.png|thumb|left|[[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington|Wellington]] appears as the cock in this cartoon depicting cock throwing from around the 1820s.]]
In 1660, an official pronouncement by Puritan officials in [[Bristol]] to forbid cock throwing (as well as cat and dog tossing) on Shrove Tuesday resulted in a riot by the apprentices.<ref name="bristol">{{cite web|url=http://weldgen.tripod.com/bristol-history/ |title=A Pictorial Record of Bristol's History |author= |date= |accessdate=19 January 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070313151113/http://weldgen.tripod.com/bristol-history/ |archivedate=13 March 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
Cock throwing's popularity slowly waned in England, as social values changed and animal welfare became a concern. [[William Hogarth]] depicted it as a barbarous activity, the first stage in a "[[slippery slope]]", in ''[[The Four Stages of Cruelty]]'' in 1751, and [[Nathan Drake (essayist and physician)|Nathan Drake]] credited this in part for changes in public attitudes to the sport. The Anglican divine and political economist [[Josiah Tucker]] also dismissed the sport as a "most cruel and barbarous diversion' in his 'Earnest and Affectionate Address to the Common People of England Concerning their Usual Recreations on Shrove Tuesday' (1753), drawing attention to the suffering and 'lingering tortures' of a 'poor innocent creature'. From the middle of the 18th century, magistrates began to deal with the problem more harshly, a marker of its loss in popularity among the "respectable" classes, imposing fines for public order offences, and local by-laws banned the practice in many places.
By the early 19th century, the tradition was all but forgotten, lingering as isolated incidents into the 1840s.<ref name="TBRS" />
{{Clear}}
==See also== *[[Fox tossing]] *[[Goose pulling]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cock Throwing}} [[Category:Animal festival or ritual]] [[Category:Animal rights]] [[Category:Blood sports]] [[Category:Cruelty to animals]]
