revision.comment: Automated edit: fixing infobox parameter "country" (violation of [[MOS:OVERLINK]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox power station | name = PS10 Solar Power Plant | name_official = ''Planta Solar 10'' | image = PS10 solar power tower.jpg | image_size = 250px | image_caption = | image_alt = | location_map = Spain | coordinates = {{coord|37|26|32|N|06|15|15|W|type:landmark_region:ES|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = | country = Spain | location = [[Sanlúcar la Mayor]], [[Seville Province]], [[Andalusia]] | status = Operational | construction_began = 2004 | commissioned = 30 March 2007{{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/andalucia/Inaugurada/Sanlucar/planta/solar/producira/energia/abastecer/toda/Sevilla/elpepuespand/20070331elpand_5/Tes |title=Inaugurada en Sanlúcar una planta solar que producirá energía para abastecer a toda Sevilla|work= ElPaís.es|date=2007-03-31}} | decommissioned = | cost = [[Euro|€]]35 million | owner = [[Abengoa Solar]] | operator = | solar_type = CSP | solar_csp_technology = T | solar_concentration = | solar_collectors = 624 | solar_collectors_area = | solar_site_area = | solar_site_resource = 2,012 kWh/m2/yr | ps_units_manu_model = | ps_electrical_capacity = 11 [[Megawatt|MW]] | ps_electrical_cap_fac = 24% | ps_annual_generation = 23.4 [[GWh]] | website = | extra = }} The '''PS10 Solar Power Plant''' ({{lang-es|Planta Solar 10}}), is the world's first commercial concentrating [[solar power tower]] operating near [[Seville]], in [[Andalusia]], [[Spain]]. The 11 [[megawatt]] (MW) solar power tower produces electricity with 624 large movable mirrors called [[heliostat]]s.{{citation |url=http://www.ens-newswire.com/ens/mar2007/2007-03-30-02.asp |title=First EU Commercial Concentrating Solar Power Tower Opens in Spain |publisher=Ens-newswire.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-25}} It took four years to build and so far cost €35 million (US$46 million).{{citation |url=http://www.electronichealing.co.uk/articles/solar_power_tower_spain.htm |title=First European Solar Power Tower |publisher=Electronic Healing |date= |accessdate=2012-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005071845/http://www.electronichealing.co.uk/articles/solar_power_tower_spain.htm |archivedate=2011-10-05 |df= }} PS10 produces about 23,400 [[megawatt-hour]]s (MW·h) per year, for which it receives €271 (US$360) per MW·h under its [[power purchase agreement]], equating to a revenue of €6.3 million per year.{{cite web |url= http://www.nrel.gov/csp/solarpaces/project_detail.cfm/projectID=38 |title= Planta Solar 10 |date= 21 April 2009 |work= Concentrating Solar Power Projects |publisher= [[National Renewable Energy Laboratory]] (NREL), [[United States Department of Energy|U.S. Dept. of Energy]] (DOE) |accessdate= 20 March 2012 }} ==Suppliers== The mirrors were delivered by [[Abengoa]], the solar receiver was designed and built by {{lang|es|Tecnical-Tecnicas Reunidas}}, a Spanish engineering company; and the Solar Tower was designed and built by ALTAC, another Spanish engineering and construction company. ==Specifications== Each of the mirrors has a surface measuring {{convert|1292|sqft|m2}} that concentrates the sun's rays to the top of a 115-meter (377 ft) high, 40-story tower where a solar receiver and a steam turbine are located. The turbine drives a generator, producing electricity. The PS10 is located 20 km west of Seville (which receives at least nine hours of sunshine 320 days per year, with 15 hours per day in mid summer). The solar receiver at the top of the tower produces [[saturated steam]] at 275 °C. The [[energy conversion efficiency]] is approximately 17%.{{cite book |title=The Geek Atlas: 128 Places Where Science & Technology Come Alive |last=Graham-Cumming |first=John |authorlink=John Graham-Cumming |year=2009 |publisher=[[O'Reilly Media]] |isbn=978-0-596-52320-6 |page=112 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HhEC0q-O1ewC&pg=PA112 |accessdate=1 March 2012}} ==Plans== [[File:PS20andPS10.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Solar Towers from left: PS10, [[PS20]].]] [[File:Foto aére de solnovas y torre junio 2010.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The first three units of Solnova. I (right) III (left, front) and IV (left rear). The two towers in the background are the PS10 and PS20 solar power stations.]] PS10 is the first of a set of [[solar power]] generation plants to be constructed in the same area that will total more than 300 MW by 2013.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} Power generation will be accomplished using a variety of technologies. The first two power plants to be brought into operation at [[Sanlúcar la Mayor]] are the PS10, and Sevilla PV, the largest low concentration system photovoltaic plant in Europe. 300 MW:
Completed and is operating: * PS10 (10 MW) * [[PS20 solar power plant|PS20]] (20 MW) * [[Solnova Solar Power Station|Solnova 1]] (50 MW) * Solnova 3 (50 MW) * Solnova 4 (50 MW) total: 180 MW. Three more plants are planned: * AZ20 (20 MW) * Solnova 2 (50 MW) * Solnova 5 (50 MW) Total 120 MW. PS20 and AZ20 are twin 20 MWe tower plants based on the same concept as PS10.{{citation |url=http://www.solarpaces.org/Tasks/Task1/ps10.htm |title=SolarPACES Home Page |publisher=Solarpaces.org |date= |accessdate=2012-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120210152851/http://www.solarpaces.org/Tasks/Task1/ps10.htm |archivedate=2012-02-10 |df= }} ==Energy storage== The PS10 solar power tower stores heat in [[Steam accumulator|tanks]] as superheated and pressurized water at 50 [[bar (unit)|bar]] and 285 °C. The water evaporates and flashes back to steam, releasing energy and reducing the pressure. Storage is for 30 minutes.http://www.abengoasolar.com/web/en/nuestras_plantas/plantas_en_operacion/espana/PS10_la_primera_torre_comercial_del_mundo.html It is suggested that longer storage is possible, but that has not been proven in an existing power plant. However, there are many considerations for using [[molten salt]] as an energy storage medium due to the great capability of storing energy for long periods without substantial losses. Another possibility is to use a [[phase-change material]] as thermal storage where [[latent heat]] is used to store energy. ==See also== {{stack|{{Portal|Spain|Sustainable development|Renewable energy}}}} * [[List of solar thermal power stations]] * [[Renewable energy in the European Union]] * [[Solar power in Spain]] * [[Solar thermal energy]] * [[Solucar]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|PS10 Solar Power Plant}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110811230017/http://ec.europa.eu/energy/res/sectors/doc/csp/ps10_final_report.pdf Final technical progress report], for [[European Union]] officials (November 2006) * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/6616651.stm Power station harnesses Sun's rays] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120210152851/http://www.solarpaces.org/Tasks/Task1/ps10.htm Description and pictures] * [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/apr/03/spain.renewableenergy Power tower reflects well on sunny Spain] {{Solar power in Europe}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ps10 Solar Power Tower}} [[Category:Solar power stations in Spain]] [[Category:Energy development]]

{{Infobox technology standard|title=Qi|image=Qi logo.svg|image_size=135|alt=The Qi logo, which consists of a round-esque, lowercase "q" with a [[semicircle]] at the right parallel to its stem and a circle on top.|caption=The Qi logo, consisting of a lowercase "q" with a [[semicircle]]-esque "i" with a circle on top, which when put together resemble an uppercase "Q". |status= Active|year_started= {{start date and age|2008}}|first_published= {{start date and age|2008}}|version=1.2.4|organization=[[Wireless Power Consortium]]|committee= [[Wireless Power Consortium]]|domain=[[Inductive charging]]|license=[[Open standard]]|copyright=[[Logo]] and [[trademark]]}}
'''Qi''' (pronounced {{IPAc-en|tʃ|iː}} {{respell|CHEE}};<ref name="wpc">{{cite web |title=Wireless Power Consortium |url=http://www.wirelesspowerconsortium.com/|accessdate= November 22, 2015}}</ref> from the [[Chinese language|Chinese]] word [[qi]]) is an [[Open standard|open]] [[interface standard]] that defines [[wireless power transfer]] using [[inductive charging]] over distances of up to 4 cm (1.6 inches), and is developed by the [[Wireless Power Consortium]].<ref name="youtube.com">{{cite web |title= eCoupled Wireless Power Through Granite | work = YouTube | publisher = [[Google]] |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1Lvd4dMloEY}}</ref> The system uses a charging pad and a compatible device, which is placed on top of the pad, charging via [[resonant inductive coupling]].<ref name="Intro">{{cite web |title= An introduction to the Wireless Power Consortium standard and TI’s compliant solutions |publisher= Ti |url= http://www.ti.com/lit/an/slyt401/slyt401.pdf |deadurl= bot: unknown |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150529010246/http://www.ti.com/lit/an/slyt401/slyt401.pdf |archivedate= 2015-05-29 |df= }}</ref>
Mobile device manufacturers that are working with the standard include [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], [[Asus]], [[Google]], [[HTC]], [[Huawei]], [[LG Electronics]], [[Motorola Mobility]], [[Nokia]], [[Samsung Electronics|Samsung]], [[BlackBerry Limited|BlackBerry]], [[Xiaomi]], and [[Sony]].<ref name="Wireless Power Consortium Members">{{cite web| publisher = Wireless Power Consortium | title = Members |url=http://www.wirelesspowerconsortium.com/member-list/}}</ref>
First released in 2008, the Qi standard had by 2016 been incorporated into more than 140 smartphones, tablets and other devices.<ref name="qi-wireless-charging.net">{{cite web|url=http://qi-wireless-charging.net/qi-enabled-phones/|title=Qi enabled Phones / Qi compatible Devices|last=|first=|date=|website=Qi Wireless Charging|access-date=September 27, 2017}}</ref>
== Features and specifications == Under the Qi specification, "low power" inductive transfers deliver power below 5 W using inductive coupling between two [[Planar transmission line|planar coil]]s. These coils are typically 5 mm apart but can be up to 40 mm and possibly farther apart.<ref name="youtube.com"/>
Regulation of the output voltage is provided by a digital control loop where the power receiver communicates with the power transmitter and requests more or less power. Communication is unidirectional from the power receiver to the power transmitter via backscatter modulation. In backscatter modulation, the power-receiver coil is loaded, changing the current draw at the power transmitter. These current changes are monitored and demodulated into the information required for the two devices to work together.<ref name="Intro" />[[File:LG WCP-300 Qi wireless charger.jpg|thumb|The bottom side of an [[LG Corporation|LG]] WCP-300 Qi charging pad]] [[File:Nokia DT-900.jpg|thumb|Opened Nokia DT-900 Qi charger]]
The WPC published the Qi low-power specification in August 2009.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ecnmag.com/article/2009/09/wireless-power-consortium-releases-095-specification|title=The Wireless Power Consortium Releases the 0.95 Specification|date=2009-09-11|work=Electronic Component News|accessdate=2017-09-27}}</ref> The Qi specification can be downloaded freely after registration.<ref name="Download">{{cite web|url=http://www.wirelesspowerconsortium.com/downloads/wireless-power-specification-part-1.html|title=Download Wireless Power Specification Part 1|last=|first=|date=|website=Wireless Power Consortium|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160403045021/https://www.wirelesspowerconsortium.com/downloads/wireless-power-specification-part-1.html|archivedate=April 3, 2016|accessdate=February 2, 2018}}</ref> In 2011, the Wireless Power Consortium began to extend the Qi specification to medium power.<ref name="Medium power extension">{{cite web|url=http://www.wirelesspowerconsortium.com/news/announcements/medium-power.html|title=Medium power extension|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311181912/https://www.wirelesspowerconsortium.com/news/announcements/medium-power.html|archive-date=11 March 2012|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The low-power specification delivers up to 5 W (typically used to charge mobile devices), and the medium-power specification will deliver up to 120 W (typically used to power displays and laptops). In 2015, WPC demonstrated a high-power specification that will deliver up to 1 kW, allowing the powering of kitchen utensils among other high-power utilities.<ref name=Download />
== Adoption == Nokia first adopted Qi in its [[Nokia Lumia 920|Lumia 920]] phone in 2012,<ref name=wiredqi>Wired, [https://www.wired.co.uk/article/what-is-qi-wireless-charging Qi Wireless Charging: What Is It And How Does It Work In Nokia's Lumia 920?], 5 September 2012</ref> and the Google/LG [[Nexus 4]] followed later that year. Toyota began offering a Qi charging cradle as a factory option on its 2013 [[Toyota Avalon|Avalon Limited]],<ref name=theverge>The Verge, [https://www.theverge.com/2012/12/19/3785166/toyota-2013-avalon-limited-first-car-qi-wireless-charging Toyota's 2013 Avalon Limited becomes world's first car to adopt Qi wireless charging], 19 December 2012</ref> with [[SsangYong Motor|Ssangyong]] the second car manufacturer to offer a Qi option, also in 2013.<ref name=torquenews>Torque News, [https://www.torquenews.com/1075/qi-wireless-charging-system-adopted-second-automaker-use-cars Qi wireless charging system adopted by second automaker for use in cars], 25 February 2013</ref>
In 2015, a survey found that 76% of people surveyed in the United States, United Kingdom, and China were aware of wireless charging (an increase from 36% the previous year), and 20% were using it — however only 16% of those using it were using it daily.<ref name=ihsmarkit>IHS Markit, [http://news.ihsmarkit.com/press-release/technology/consumer-awareness-wireless-charging-doubles-76-percent-2015-ihs-says Consumer Awareness of Wireless Charging Doubles to 76 Percent in 2015, IHS Says], 24 June 2015</ref> Furniture retailer [[IKEA]] introduced lamps and tables with integrated wireless chargers for sale in 2015,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Matt|title=IKEA will start selling wireless charging lamps and tables|url=https://www.engadget.com/2015/02/28/ikea-wireless-charging/|website=Engadget|accessdate=1 March 2015}}</ref> and the [[Lexus NX]] gained an optional Qi charging pad in the center console.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lexus.com/models/NX-hybrid/features/wireless-charger|title=Wireless Charger - Unbound Convenience|last=|first=|date=|website=www.lexus.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209131617/http://www.lexus.com/models/NX-hybrid/features/wireless-charger|archive-date=2015-02-09|dead-url=yes|access-date=2017-08-07}}</ref> An estimated 120 million wirelessly charging phones were sold that year,<ref name=ihsmarkit /> notably the [[Samsung Galaxy S6]], which supported both Qi and the competing [[Power Matters Alliance]] standards.<ref name=wiredmess>Wired, [https://www.wired.com/2015/11/wireless-charging-airfuel-resence-qi-wpc/ Wireless Charging Is Still a Mess, But It Won’t Be Forever], 12 November 2015</ref> However, the existence of several competing wireless charging standards was still seen as a barrier to adoption.<ref name=wiredmess />
By early 2017, Qi had displaced the competing standards, with no new products featuring Rezence.<ref name=eandt>E&T, [https://eandt.theiet.org/content/articles/2017/02/qi-wireless-charging-standard-emerges-victorious-adoption-rapidly-increasing/ Qi wireless charging standard emerges victorious; adoption rapidly increasing], 17 February 2017</ref> On September 12, 2017, [[Apple Inc.]] announced that their new smartphones, the [[iPhone 8]], [[iPhone 8|iPhone 8 Plus]], and the [[iPhone X]], will support the Qi standard. Apple also announced plans to expand the standard with a new protocol called [[AirPower (hardware)|AirPower]] which would have added the ability to charge multiple devices at once.
As the Qi standard gains popularity, it is expected that ''Qi Hotspots'' will begin to arise in places such as coffee shops, airports, sports arenas, etc.<ref name="prnewswire.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/global-qi-standard-powers-up-wireless-charging-102043348.html|title=Global Qi Standard Powers Up Wireless Charging}}</ref> [[The Coffee Bean and Tea Leaf]], a major US coffee chain, will install inductive charging stations at selected major metropolitan cities,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://press.nokia.com/2012/09/05/nokia-and-the-coffee-bean-tea-leaf%C2%AE-form-partnership-to-introduce-wireless-charging-to-cafes-across-the-united-states/|title=Nokia and The Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf® form partnership to introduce wireless charging to cafés across the United States|publisher=Nokia|date=September 5, 2012|accessdate=September 21, 2012}}</ref> as well as [[Virgin Atlantic Airways]], for United Kingdom's [[London Heathrow Airport]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://press.nokia.com/2012/09/05/nokia-and-virgin-atlantic-partner-to-introduce-wireless-charging-to-virgin-atlantic-clubhouse-lounges/|title=Nokia and Virgin Atlantic partner to introduce wireless charging to Virgin Atlantic Clubhouse Lounges|publisher=Nokia|date=September 5, 2012|accessdate=September 21, 2012}}</ref> and New York City's [[John F. Kennedy International Airport]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://conversations.nokia.com/2012/09/11/nokia-flies-virgin-atlantic-on-wireless-charging/|title=Nokia flies Virgin Atlantic on wireless charging|publisher=Nokia|date=September 11, 2012|accessdate=September 21, 2012}}</ref> Automobile manufacturers have been adding QI charging as standard or optional features since 2013.
== System overview == Devices that operate with the Qi standard rely on [[electromagnetic induction]] between planar [[Electromagnetic coil|coils]]. A Qi system consists of two types of devices – the Base Station, which is connected to a power source and provides inductive power, and Mobile Devices, which consume inductive power. The Base Station contains a power transmitter that comprises a transmitting coil that generates an oscillating [[magnetic field]]; the Mobile Device contains a power receiver holding a receiving coil. The magnetic field induces an [[alternating current]] in the receiving coil by [[Faraday's law of induction]]. Close spacing of the two coils, as well as shielding on their surfaces, ensure the inductive power transfer is efficient.
Base Stations typically have a flat surface—referred to as the Interface Surface—on top of which a user can place one or more Mobile Devices. There are two methods for aligning the transmitting coil (part of the Base Station) and receiving coil (part of the Mobile Device) in order for a power transfer to happen. In the first concept—called guided positioning—a user must place the Mobile Device on a certain location of the Base Station's surface. For this purpose, the Mobile Device provides an alignment aid that is appropriate to its size, shape and function. The second concept—referred to as free positioning—does not require the user to place the Mobile Device in direct alignment with the transmitting coil. There are several ways to achieve free positioning. In one example a bundle of transmitting coils is used to generate a magnetic field at the location of the receiving coil only. Another example uses mechanical means to move a single transmitting coil underneath the receiving coil. A third option is to use a technique called "Multiple Cooperative Flux Generators."<ref>{{cite web|title=Variable Position Wireless Power Transmitter through Multiple Cooperative Flux Generators|url=http://www.wirelesspowerconsortium.com/technology/multiple-cooperative-flux-generators.html}}</ref>[[Image:Qi wireless power interface specification - basic system overview.png|thumb|Fig. 1-1]]Figure 1-1 illustrates the basic system configuration. As shown, a power transmitter includes two main functional units—a power conversion unit and a communications and control unit. The diagram shows the transmitting coil (array) generating the magnetic field as part of the power conversion unit. The control and communications unit regulates the transferred power to the level that the power receiver requests. The diagram also demonstrates that a Base Station may contain numerous transmitters, allowing for multiple Mobile Devices to be placed on the same Base Station and inductively charge until each of its batteries are fully charged. Finally, the system unit in the diagram comprises all other functionality of the Base Station, such as input power provisioning, control of multiple power transmitters, and user interfacing.
A power receiver comprises a power pick-up unit, as well as a communications and control unit. Similar to the power conversion unit of the transmitter, Figure 1-1 illustrates the receiving coil as capturing the magnetic field of the power pick-up unit. A power pick-up unit typically contains a single receiving coil only. Moreover, a Mobile Device typically contains a single power receiver. The communications and control unit regulates the transferred power to the level that is appropriate for the subsystems (e.g., battery) connected to the output of the power receiver. These subsystems represent the main functionality of the Mobile Device.
=== Example Power Transmitter Hardware === As an example from the 2017 version 1.2.2 of the Qi specification (referenced above), the A2 reference Qi low-power transmitter has a coil of 20 turns (in two layers) in a flat coil, wound on a form with a 19mm inner diameter and a 40mm outer diameter, with a below-coil shield of soft iron at least 4mm larger in diameter which gives an inductance of 24 +-1 microhenries. This coil is placed in a series resonant circuit with a 200 nF capacitor to yield a resonant circuit with a natural resonance at ~140 kHz when coupled to the receiver coil.
This series resonant circuit is then driven by an H-bridge switching arrangement from the DC source; at full power, the voltage in the capacitor can reach 50 volts. Power control is automatic; the Qi specification requires that the actual voltage applied be controllable in steps at least as small as 50 millivolts.
Rather than down-regulate the charging voltage in the device, Qi chargers meeting the A2 reference use a PID (proportional-integral-derivative) controller to modulate the delivered power according to the primary cell voltage.
Other Qi charge transmitters start their connections at 140 kHz, but can change frequencies to find a frequency with a better match, as the mutual inductance between transmitter and receiver coils will vary according to the standoff distance between transmitter and receiver coils, and thus the natural resonance frequency will vary. Different Qi reference designs have different coil arrangements, including oval coil and multi-coil systems as well as more complex resonance networks with multiple inductors and capacitors. These designs allow frequency-agile operation at frequencies from 105 to 205 kHz and with maximum resonant circuit voltages as high as 200 volts.
=== Example Power Receiver Hardware === The Qi power receiver hardware reference design 1, also from version 1.2.2 of the Qi specification, starts with a rectangular coil of wire 44mm x 30mm outside size, with 14 turns of wire, and with an above-coil magnetic shield. This coil is wired into a parallel resonant circuit with a pair of capacitors (of 127 nanofarads and 1.6 nanofarads in series). The power output is taken across the 1.6 nanofarad capacitor.
In order to provide a digital communications channel back to the power transmitter, a resonance modulator consisting of a pair of 22 nanofarad capacitors and a 10kΩ resistor in a T configuration can be switched across the 1.6 nanofarad capacitor. Switching the T network across the 1.6 nanofarad capacitor causes a significant change in the resonant frequency of the coupled system that is detected by the power transmitter as a change in the delivered power.
Power output to the portable device is via a full-wave bridge wired across the 1.6 nanofarad capacitor; the power is typically filtered with a 20 microfarad capacitor before delivery to the charge controller.
Other Qi power receivers use alternate resonance modulators, including switching a resistor or pair of resistors across the receiver resonator capacitor, both before and after the bridge rectifier.
== See also == * [[Wireless power transfer]] * [[Inductive coupling]] * [[Resonant inductive coupling]] * [[Near field communication]] * [[Rezence (wireless charging standard)|Rezence]], a competing wireless power standard promoted by The Alliance for Wireless Power and the Power Matters Alliance * [[WiPower]], a formerly competing wireless power standard promoted by The Alliance For Wireless Power that merged with PMA to form Rezence * [[Power Matters Alliance|PMA]], a formerly competing wireless power standard promoted by the Power Matters Alliance that merged with WiPower to form Rezence * [[Open Dots]], a competing wireless power standard promoted by the Open Dots Alliance
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == * {{Official website|https://www.wirelesspowerconsortium.com|Qi}} – official site * [http://qi-wireless-charging.net/check/ Compatibility check to find out whether your device supports Qi or not] * {{Cite web|title=Is Qi Ready to Be the Standard for Wireless Power?|work=Popular Science|accessdate=2009-08-21|url=http://www.popsci.com/gear-amp-gadgets/article/2009-08/qi-ready-be-wireless-charging-standard}} * {{Cite news|title=Wireless Power Spec Nears Completion - News and Analysis by PC Magazine|accessdate=2009-08-21|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2351686,00.asp|first=Mark|last=Hachman|date=2009-08-17}} * {{cite news|title=Is there a realistic future for power without wire?|work=The Guardian|accessdate=2009-08-21|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2009/aug/19/power-without-wires|location=London|first=Jack|last=Schofield|date=2009-08-19}}
